Award.AbstractNarration:
This multi-year (2012-2016) proposal is for continuation of WHOI?s management of the Fleet Broadband (FBB) Satellite Communication program for up to 70 UNOLS research ships, special platforms, and OOI platforms. The project has been on-going since 2008 and is currently supported by a five year contract from 2010 ? 2014 between WHOI and satellite communication providers Inmarsat, Stratos, and World- Link. Current scope of services include: 102 GB of data per month, voice services, antenna procurement, maintenance and repair and application support, and administration.

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under criterion two, providing infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The support of maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
WHOI has completed management of the NSF 2012-2019 Fleet Broadband (FBB) Support Program, Award Number 1256051 (Supplement OCE-1844566). This program supported up to 100 UNOLS research ships, special platforms, OOI platforms and 10 Fleet Xpress (Fx) Systems on UNOLS ships. The contract between WHOI and World-Link expired on 31 December 2019.

Up to 100 research platforms including ships and OOI platforms were supported by this FBB Support Program. Over 75 FBB systems were operating in the pool and 11 Fx Systems were in place providing communication capability to a large variety of NSF research projects. Knowledge gained and the discoveries made by the research programs supported by these platforms enhanced understanding of the oceans and addressed a broad range of important scientific questions. The goal of this program was to provide systems to effectively and productively communicate discoveries by science at sea to research laboratories and schools (grades K-12) throughout the USA and the world in real time. Effective and affordable communications were prerequisites for all voyages. Additionally, state-of-the-art communication systems enhanced the safety of each of these ships by improving both the voice and data linkage between ship and shore. 

The research platforms supported by this support program provide at-sea laboratories the means to effectively and safely take science to sea or gather data at sea and transport it back to shore.  This community included senior oceanographic scientists, post-doctoral and doctoral students, graduate and undergrad students as well as engineers, technicians, and teachers. These intellectual endeavors have broadened our understanding and have prompted new questions and scientific theory.
